https://prez.dev/description.@value: The point or level from which heights and depths are measured and referenced to for an entity or activity. Typically these are expressed relative to a common global or regional reference datum such as the Australian Height Datum (AHD) or can be related to local reference systems. Specific emphasis is placed on elevation references used by resource exploration and drilling programs, whereby depths are measured relative to local reference datums or specific parts of a borehole/drilling platform. Concepts in this vocabulary include both reference datums (e.g. mean sea level) and how depths are expressed relative to them (e.g. mean sea level height).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#altL.@value: BDF â€“ Below rig derrick floor

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The drill floor (DF), also known as derrick floor, is the working area in which the rig crew conducts drilling operations, and is often used as a reference point for downhole/depth measurements. Depth measurements are commonly referenced to the DF, with notations like 2538 m DF or 2358 m BDF, indicating 2538 m below the drill/derrick floor.
